repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
**Problem:** Currently, if users want to efficiently disable injections, they have to delete the injection query files at their runtime path. This is because we only check for existence of the files before running the query over the entire buffer.

**Solution:** Check for existence of query files, *and* that those files actually have captures. This will allow users to just comment out existing queries (or better yet, just add their own injection query to `~/.config/nvim` which contains only comments) to disable running the query over the entire buffer (a potentially slow operation)

comment_data.body:
This doesn't do anything right? Just the existence of the file disables the injections? Unlike `; inherits` and `; extends`.

If so then this is slightly confusing.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -573,6 +573,14 @@ associated with patterns:
     • `injection.parent` - indicates that the captured node’s text should
       be parsed with the same language as the node's parent LanguageTree.
 
+Injection queries are currently run over the entire buffer, which can be slow
+for large buffers. To disable injections for a certain language, just place an
+empty query file in your 'runtimepath'. For example, to disable injections for
+`c`, use the following `queries/c/injections.scm`: >query
+
+    ; disabled

comment_data.body: Yeah, true. Should I just remove this example then? Maybe does more harm than good.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -573,6 +573,14 @@ associated with patterns:
     • `injection.parent` - indicates that the captured node’s text should
       be parsed with the same language as the node's parent LanguageTree.
 
+Injection queries are currently run over the entire buffer, which can be slow
+for large buffers. To disable injections for a certain language, just place an
+empty query file in your 'runtimepath'. For example, to disable injections for
+`c`, use the following `queries/c/injections.scm`: >query
+
+    ; disabled

comment_data.body: I think it's better to explicitly describe what happens, and/or use a comment that us obviously arbitrary.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -573,6 +573,14 @@ associated with patterns:

+empty query file in your 'runtimepath'. For example, to disable injections for
+`c`, use the following `queries/c/injections.scm`: >query
+
+    ; disabled

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
query file containing only a comment in your 'runtimepath'. For example, to disable injections for
```

("empty" would mean "no contents", not even comments)

comment_data.body: You mean adding an empty file? I was under the impression that it had to have _some_ contents and empty file was not enough. In that case, the documentation can (and should) be simplified significantly.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -573,6 +573,15 @@ associated with patterns:
     • `injection.parent` - indicates that the captured node’s text should
       be parsed with the same language as the node's parent LanguageTree.
 
+Injection queries are currently run over the entire buffer, which can be slow
+for large buffers. To disable injections for a certain language, just place an
+empty query file in your 'runtimepath'. For example, to disable injections for

comment_data.body: The file just needs to exist to prevent other files being loaded. We can then use `extends` or `inherits` to pull in other files.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -573,6 +573,15 @@ associated with patterns:
     • `injection.parent` - indicates that the captured node’s text should
       be parsed with the same language as the node's parent LanguageTree.
 
+Injection queries are currently run over the entire buffer, which can be slow
+for large buffers. To disable injections for a certain language, just place an
+empty query file in your 'runtimepath'. For example, to disable injections for

comment_data.body: OK, then that was a misunderstanding on my part; let's just document empty query then.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -573,6 +573,15 @@ associated with patterns:
     • `injection.parent` - indicates that the captured node’s text should

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
Injection queries are currently run over the entire buffer, which can be slow
for large buffers. To disable injections for, e.g.,  `c`, just place an
empty `queries/c/injections.scm` file in your 'runtimepath'.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -573,6 +573,15 @@ associated with patterns:
     • `injection.parent` - indicates that the captured node’s text should
       be parsed with the same language as the node's parent LanguageTree.
 
+Injection queries are currently run over the entire buffer, which can be slow
+for large buffers. To disable injections for a certain language, just place an
+empty query file in your 'runtimepath'. For example, to disable injections for
+`c`, use the following `queries/c/injections.scm`: >query
+
+    ; This file contains no captures (only comments), thus injections are
+    ; ignored for this language.
+    ; Note that these comments are arbitrary and not necessary.
+

comment_data.body: But wouldn't it also be helpful to know that the file can be either empty, or contain only comments?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -573,6 +573,15 @@ associated with patterns:
     • `injection.parent` - indicates that the captured node’s text should
       be parsed with the same language as the node's parent LanguageTree.
 
+Injection queries are currently run over the entire buffer, which can be slow
+for large buffers. To disable injections for a certain language, just place an

+
+    ; This file contains no captures (only comments), thus injections are
+    ; ignored for this language.
+    ; Note that these comments are arbitrary and not necessary.
+

comment_data.body: At this point, people only need to know how to disable injections, and the simplest way will do. (It just has to be correct, not complete.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_data.body: (and I think if the comment happens to be `; extends`, then it _won't_ disable anything -- and now things become too complicated to explain in full)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -573,6 +573,15 @@ associated with patterns:
     • `injection.parent` - indicates that the captured node’s text should

comment_data.body: Sure. I still feel like I would personally get confused by an empty file and think it was a mistake, thus I would like  a comment explaining its purpose, but I guess the user could fiddle around for 30 seconds and figure things out
comment_data.diff_hunk:

comment_regular_data.body: Rebase and rerun CI, then LGTM!

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability

title: fix(treesitter): disable injections by commenting out queries
